metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State (Criminal Appeal Nos. 130 and 25 of 1956)
metadata.case_number: Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 and Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956, the appellant was convicted under s.5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 by the Special Judge, Delhi and sentenced to six months simple imprisonment.
The appellant in Cr A No. 130/56 appealed to the Punjab High Court, which dismissed the appeal and enhanced the sentence to two years rigorous imprisonment.
Special leave granted in Cr A No. 130/56 limited to whether the trial court had jurisdiction to take cognizance without sanction under s.6 of the Act.
In Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956, the appellant applied to Allahabad High Court under s.561A CrPC to quash proceedings before Special Judge; application dismissed.
At the time the Special Judge purported to take cognizance, appellants were not public servants, but they were public servants at the time of the alleged offence.
No order of sanction under s.6 of the Act by competent authority was on record.
Appellant in Cr A No. 25/56 appointed Deputy Assistant Director Enforcement on March 25, 1949; promoted to Assistant Director on July 14, 1949.
Alleged acceptance of Rs.10,000 bribe on September 11, 1951 as part payment of Rs.30,000.
Appellant in Cr A No. 25/56 dismissed from service on September 25, 1953 after enquiry under r.55 Civil Service Rules.
Final report under s.173 CrPC submitted September 18, 1952 stating prosecution recommended but Ministry ordered departmental dealing.
Magistrate approved closing investigation on September 19, 1952, discharged appellant from bail, ordered return of Rs.10,000 to complainant.
Prosecution recommenced on February 11, 1954 on fresh complaint with same materials and allegations.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was necessity for sanction under s.6 of Prevention of Corruption Act before court could take cognizance of offence under s.161 IPC or s.5(2) of the Act alleged to have been committed by a person who was a public servant at time of commission but not at time court asked to take cognizance.
Whether prosecution could be recommenced after earlier final report and closure by Magistrate in Cr A No. 25/56.

petitioner_arguments.text: Status of accused at time of commission of offence is essence; sanction under s.6 necessary even if ceased to be public servant by time of cognizance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act; s.197 CrPC; precedents like S.Y. Patil v. Vyankatswami

petitioner_arguments.text: Once sanction refused or prosecution dropped, cannot be revived; abuse of process to recommence.

respondent_arguments.text: Sanction required only if person still public servant at time court asked to take cognizance; offence must be by public servant but accused must still be employed and not removable except by competent authority.
No positive refusal of sanction; Government proceeded departmentally first; earlier closure was discharge, not bar to fresh complaint; at time of fresh complaint, appellant not public servant.

court_reasoning.text: s.6 requires two conditions: offence committed by public servant AND accused still public servant (employed in connection with Union/State affairs not removable save by Central/State Govt or other competent authority) at time of cognizance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If either condition lacking, no sanction needed; accused ceased to be public servant, so provisions inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: Words in s.6(1) clear: 'alleged to have been committed by a public servant'; clauses (a),(b),(c) refer to current status as employed/not removable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot substitute 'was employed' for 'is employed'; cl.(c) covers other current public servants.

court_reasoning.text: s.6(2) resolves doubt on sanctioning authority based on time of offence, but does not alter s.6(1) requiring current public servant status.
Precedents on s.197 CrPC support: protection only if public servant at time of accusation/cognizance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.6 to be construed independently but similar principle.

court_reasoning.text: No positive refusal of sanction; departmental proceedings first; earlier withdrawal led to discharge, not final acquittal; fresh complaint valid post-cessation of service.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No promise not to prosecute; court could take cognizance without sanction on Feb 11, 1954.

holdings.text: No sanction under s.6 required if accused not public servant at time of cognizance, even if was at time of offence.
Prosecution validly recommenced; no bar after discharge on final report when sanction not positively refused.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher
precedents_cited.relevance: On construing ambiguous statutes; not applicable here as s.6 clear.
Held s.197 protects ex-public servant; overruled later.
Similar on s.197 for ex-public servant.
s.197 requires public servant at time of accusation.
s.197 protection only if still public servant at prosecution launch.
s.197 and s.6 similar; no protection post-discharge.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction required only if accused still public servant at cognizance for offences under s.161/164/165 IPC or s.5(2); creates offence of criminal misconduct.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences requiring sanction; defines public servant.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to take cognizance prohibited without sanction if conditions met; s.197 analogous but independent.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Appoints Special Judges to try specified offences without committal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Referred but not assistive in construing s.6.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held no sanction under s.6 PCA required as appellants not public servants at time of cognizance; provisions inapplicable. For Cr A 25/56, no refusal of sanction and fresh prosecution valid post-discharge. Appeals dismissed, upholding trial court jurisdiction and proceedings.

key_quotes.text: "No court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 164 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code... alleged to have been committed by a public servant, except with the previous sanction..."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Both these conditions must be present to prevent a court from taking cognizance... If either of these conditions is lacking, the essential requirements of the section are wanting."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on dual conditions for s.6 applicability.

key_quotes.text: "A public servant who has ceased to be a public servant is not a person removable from any office by a competent authority."
key_quotes.speaker: court
